children.subject: In theory, an instructor probably can require in-person exams as long as it doesn't conflict with university policy, but I hope most instructors are empathetic enough to offer a remote exam option.
I have the same question for other cs classes like 170 and 188. Will all the remote courses have remote exams or options to do exams remotely?
I have a feeling that since the lecture is remote, and some homework and lab sections are offered remote, there must be a remote exam option.

history.content: The enrollment managers, Cindy Conners and Gina Garcia, are working with the faculty who have sections that are online to determine the answer to this question, but it's not yet determined.

children.subject: Mid-July at the earliest. Latest is a few days before the start of instruction
When can we expect a response for this?

From one month ago, here is one of his responses:

It is going to be largely on a per-instructor basis.

Large classes for the most part can still assume most/all students are available in person, since we also have discussion/lab included in those classes. Combined with the inevitable need to space out seating anyway the <200 person per room limit for an exam (rather than a lecture) is simply not a problem.

For my classes (CS61C, CS161) I'm probably going to go with an in-person centric hybrid approach: The exam is in person for all students in the area, but if a student is out of the area or is a DSP student needing a low distraction environment they will take the exam using a remote tool like the 61A ExamTool.

If I was confident there were enough power strips available in the rooms where the exams are given I'd even consider "in-person proctored online", where the students are in person but taking the test on their computers. The problem is unless the exam is in the law school most lecture halls do not have enough power plugs under the seats.

Another response:

We will provide both a simultaneous webcast and a recorded webcast of a small (40 person or so) in-person lecture. We will support remote exams for out of area individuals but anyone who have otherwise in-person activity will have in-person exams.
I wonder if those plans changed.

If you have a special circumstance like a need for a DSP accommodation, you should definitely contact the instructor and/or the Head GSI near the beginning of the Fall semester. You should have a letter from DSP (the Disabled Students Program) that spells out the accommodations that you need, and you can attach that.

If you are overseas and have a visa issue, faculty definitely understand that, though you may need to provide some documentation.

The same is true if you have a health issue that prevents your return to campus. You should just plan to have documentation that you can send to faculty or to the Disabled Students Program (a disability can be longer or shorter term) that will allow for you to have accommodations.

You should ask Nick or one of the head TAs for confirmation, but I believe the plan for 61C is to hold exams in-person, but offer a remote exam option for extenuating circumstances (e.g. DSP accommodation, not in Berkeley, etc.)
I don't think anybody has an answer to this yet. It will probably be up to the instructors' discretion, and hopefully a policy will be finalized by the start of the semester.
I live in San Jose, CA. Would not having to commute be a valid reason to take an exam remotely?

history.content: Since CS 61C has the mode of instruction for lecture as remote, do you expect all exam delivery to be remote?
